contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox protected area of Australia | name = Mount Walsh National Park | iucn_category = II | image = BiggendenMtWalsh.JPG | caption = Mount Walsh | locator_x = | locator_y = | nearest_town_or_city = Biggenden, Queensland | coordinates = {{Coord|25|35|52|S|152|03|07|E|type:landmark_region:AU-QLD|display=inline,title}} | area = {{Convert|52.40|km2|sqmi|2|abbr=on}} | established = 1947 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | managing_authorities = [[Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service]] | official_site = [http://www.derm.qld.gov.au/parks/mount-walsh/index.html Mount Walsh National Park] }} '''Mount Walsh''' is a national park in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]], 230 km northwest of [[Brisbane]]. A prominent landmark in the Biggenden region is the granite bluff area of Mount Walsh which rises to 703 m above sea leven in the northern part of park. The summit has three peaks.<ref name="naq">{{cite book |title=Natural Areas of Queensland |last=Shilton |first=Peter |year=2005 |publisher=Goldpress |location=Mount Gravatt, Queensland |isbn=0-9758275-0-2 |pages=140–141 |accessdate=28 June 2011}}</ref> Exposed granite outcrops, rugged ridges and steep forested slopes support a range of vegetation. The “Bluff” area of Mount Walsh is located at the park’s northern end and is a prominent landmark of the Biggenden area.<ref name="dermmwnp">{{cite web |url=http://www.derm.qld.gov.au/parks/mount-walsh/index.html |title=Mount Walsh National Park |date=9 June 2011 |publisher=Department of Environment and Resource Management |accessdate=28 June 2011 }}</ref> The park features sheltered gullies, rugged ridge lines with mountain areas with spectacular exposed granite outcrops and cliffs support a diversity of vegetation. Such diversity gives a home to many endangered animal species such as the [[Powerful Owl]] and [[Grey Goshawk]]. Visitors may also see [[Peregrine Falcon]]s, [[Dingo]]es, [[wallaby|Wallabies]], [[Eastern Grey Kangaroo]]s and [[Lace Monitor]]s.<ref name="naq"/> A complex landscape has led to diverse vegetation communities which includes heath, shrubland, woodland, open forest and dry forest.<ref name="naq"/> There are patches of [[Hoop Pine]]s in some gullies. ==Geology== The geological history of the mountain began in the late Triassic period about 215 million years ago. Violent explosions emanated from a volcanic structure referred to as the Mungore Centre.<ref name="naq"/> Two large bodies of [[magma]] rose close to the surface where Mount Malarga and Mount Walsh are presently situated. Erosion has left the cliffs, buffs, gorges rocky pavements and tors seen today.<ref name="naq"/> ==Facilities== Picnic and barbecue facilities are available. Bush camping is allowed in the park.<ref name="dermmwnp"/> No facilities are provided so visitors must be totally self-sufficient. ===Walking tracks=== A 300 metre trail from the picnic area leads visitors through open eucalypt forest to a rocky creek gully fringed in rain forest,<ref name="qhmwnp">{{cite web |url=http://www.queenslandholidays.com.au/things-to-see-and-do/mount-walsh-national-park/index.cfm |title=Things to do and see: Mount Walsh National Park|work=Queensland Holidays |publisher=Tourism Queensland |accessdate=28 June 2011 }}</ref> then on to lookouts over surrounding countryside.<ref name="dermmwnp"/> Experienced walkers can take the strenuous (unmarked) two and a half hour hike to Mount Walsh's bare granite summit.<ref name="dermmwnp"/> You will be rewarded with stunning views. ==See also== {{Portal|Queensland}} * [[Protected areas of Queensland]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.qld.gsa.org.au/walsh.pdf Rocks and Landscape Notes: Mount Walsh, Biggenden] - Geological Society of Australia: Queensland Division {{National Parks of Queensland}} [[Category:National parks of Queensland]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1947]] [[Category:Central Queensland]] [[Category:1947 establishments in Australia]]
